8. Nxe4 Bxg5 9. Nxg5 Qxg5 10. Nxd7 Bxd7 is also possible and judging by the game continuation probably better

This not much of a threat although and with Black's Queen having open space on my Kingside the eventual castle that I make is probably not such a good idea in any case. I might have been better served with something like 9. Nxe5 dxe5 10. c5

Nicely protecting the Knight in that excellent forward position
I think this is a mistake with both Knights on that side of the board and the potential for the Queen to come in at a moments notice
Forces my Bishop back and gains a pawn. I think this is better than 11. ... Nxe4 12. b3 even though Black ends up with doubled pawns. The forward e-pawn is not bad at all

I think this is also a mistake. It undoubles the pawns, allows Black's Knight into a strong square although does give me the f-file for my Rook. Better perhaps is 14. Re1 protecting my Bishop and allowing my Queen to get into the game.
Easily refuting my attack.

Easily refuting my attack.

Retreating the Bishop is perhaps a better move but I wanted to make an active game and perhaps even get a mating attack with something like: 16. ... gxh5 17. Qxh5 Kh8 18. Nxf7+ Kg8 19. Qg4+ Ng5 20. Qxg5# although none of that is forced
My opponent looks to trade Queens and pick up the Bishop
Naturally I cannot allow that to happen
This removes the potential attack on the f7 pawn
Now my Bishop is trapped and I have to make the most of a bad situation
Immediately capturing the Bishop leads to a bit of a King chase with 18. ... hxg6 19. Nxg6 Rd8 20. Qh5 b6 21. Qh8+ etc or something of the like
18. ... Nf6 covers the h5 square and prevents my Queen from coming in on the attack after hxg6 so I have to retreat my Bishop which leads to the loss of several pawns.
